newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexico stocks rebound on foreign buying.
newsitem.headline: Mexico stocks rebound on foreign buying.

text.p: Mexican stocks rebounded from their earlier slump to approach resistance at record levels in mid-afternoon trade on Friday, after foreign buyers stepped into the market.

"It's crazy down here. Foreign buyers broke loose in a big way. I think they want to snap up positions at good prices ahead of the weekend," a floor trader said. The leading IPC share index was up 19.50 points, or 0.55 percent, at 3597.84.
"We're heading for resistance at 3,600 points and we may take a break there," the trader added.
The Dow Jones meanwhile soared 1.18 percent to a new record close of 6,703.79 points.

Traders said the bourse slumped in early trade on fallout from an initial surge in yields on U.S. 30-year Treasury bonds to 6.90 percent, but recovered in tandem with the Dow as long bond yields receded to 6.85 percent in late trade.

"Foreigners have stepped in to buy short-term positions, which has fueled the IPC rally. This implies they may see further gains in coming sessions," said Hector Jimenez, an analyst with the Inverlat financial group.
"Nonetheless, the bourse did not manage to climb above resistance at 3,600 points, which implies it is trying to consolidate with light profit-taking to bolster a renewed advance," Jimenez added.
Another analyst said investors were buying on an improved outlook for economic growth ahead of potential political stumbling blocks.
"Mexico looks good this year. I feel dealers are picking up paper that is still well priced before jitters intrude half-way through the year with (mid-term) elections," an equity analyst said.
On the broad market, a total of 119 stocks were traded, with gains outnumbering losses by 55 to 39.
Financial stock Serfin was a notable gainer, up 30 centavos to 3.43 pesos, which traders said benefitted from technical buy signals.
Debt-ridden holding group Sidek headed the falls, down 10 centavos to 80 centavos.
